turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Good morning. I'm Doctor Smith from Babylon. Can you just confirm your name, date of birth, and the first line of your address please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hi. My name is Susan. Um, thirty, <UNSURE>Redbridge</UNSURE> Street, SW two two HZ.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Are you in a private place <UNSURE>so</UNSURE> you can have a consultation today?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and how long has that been going on for?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Six days, OK. And just tell me a bit more about that. How did it start?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I've got this thing when I pee, and it hurts when I go to the loo, and I've got this very unpleasant smell that comes out.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, have you had any other symptoms along with that? Have you had any abdominal pain, or back, lower back pain at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I've got, pain in my tummy.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Is it one-sided, or in <UNSURE>the</UNSURE> middle?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And how bad would you say that is on a scale of one to ten? With ten being <UNSURE>the</UNSURE> worst pain.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And is it, constant, or does it come and go?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And have you actually been able to pass water OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes, but I've had <UNSURE>spotted</UNSURE>, uh, blood in my urine. Spots.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And is that just over the last, six days?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right. And have you been able to eat and drink OK?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and, have you had a temperature? Do you feel like you've been feverish, or had a temperature with this?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and any, did you <UNIN/>, you said you didn't have any lower back pain?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, and no loin pain as well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, have you had these symptoms before?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And was there anything you were doing recently, which you think may have contributed to it? Have you <UNIN/>, have you been doing lots of exercise, been dehydrated, um, been having regular sexual intercourse or anything?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, OK. And, any, any other symptoms, any vaginal discharge or, anything like that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, just the blood spot, in my.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and <UNIN/>, in the past, have you had any medical problems at all?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you had any problems with your kidneys, or any urine infections?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And how's that been recently? Any change in your bowel habit? Any blood when you pass stool?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, I've had spotting in my urine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: In <UNSURE>your</UNSURE>, OK. Um, any change in your bowel habit? Any weight loss or anything?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any other medical problems, or surgery in the past?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And it, do you take it three times a day?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And anyone in your family had any medical problems?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That's fine. And whereabouts, do you live? Do you live with friends, family?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And where do you work? What's your job?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Do you drink alcohol at all?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So how much in a average week?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: One glass of wine a week.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um, it sounds very much like you, might have an infection in your urine. Did you say, you haven't felt feverish?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you got a thermometer at home?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. It would be helpful if you could get a thermometer from the pharmacy and, do check your temperature, just to make sure that it isn't, going up and down.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, normally we can treat this infection without having to test your urine. Uh, with, with a course of antibiotics.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, how do you feel about that? Are you happy to take a course of antibiotics?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: It would just be for three days.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yes, so I can send a prescription through to your requested pharmacy for that. If you take them, as soon as you can, get them, pick them up as soon as you can, and start taking them.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: The other thing which is important to do is to drink, lots of water. So, two and a half to three litres a day.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, you can get some cranberry juice and take, drink that as well, that sometimes helps. And also some, sachets um, which you can get from the chemist, some sachets which just help change the acidity of your urine. So I, I can put the details of that on your notes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, if you feel like your pain is getting worse or not settling, you get lower back pain, um, or you're getting a high temperature, or you have any problems actually passing urine. Then it's very important that we speak to you again.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, the other thing is that if it becomes a, common, thing or a recurrent problem. Then we need to talk to you again about it.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So, do I have to call after I finish my course of antibiotics.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, not if you're better. If you're, if you feel like your symptoms get worse at any point, or they're not resolving with the treatment. Or you keep getting a similar, um, you keep getting a similar, problem, reccurently. Then it's important for us to talk, talk to you in more detail about that.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, have you got any other questions?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no. Uh, <UNSURE>where will</UNSURE> be the pharmacy I'll be picking up, my medication from?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, so have you already requested a pharmacy through Babylon?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Can I just check that with you?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, that's fine. So the antibiotics, that I'm gonna prescribe, um, will go through to that, pharmacy.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And <UNSURE>then</UNSURE> <UNIN/>, you'll be able to pick them up from there.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: How soon is that gonna be, at the practice? In five minutes?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, I would give it longer than that. Give it a, an hour or so.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: All right then. Thank you, I'll pick that at lunchtime.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. All right then. Take care. Bye.
